biogHist.abstract: The Graceville Centre was the new name given in 1974 to what had been known since 1903 as Graceville. A Salvation Army Rescue Home, Graceville had replaced Cornelie Home at Highgate. By1974 the Graceville Centre in Highgate was a complex of buildings accommodating: mothers and children temporarily; women aged 16-25 for alcohol rehabilitation; and, young and older women attending special schools and sheltered workshops. In 2013 the temporary accommodation services continued in an undisclosed location.
biogHist.p: The Graceville Centre began its long history in 1898 as Cornelie Home; a Rescue Home for women and a maternity home for 'unmarried mothers'. After the maternity program was transferred to North Fremantle in 1903, Cornelie remained a Rescue Home with room for 21 women and its name changed to Graceville. On 22 March 1922, Graceville was registered as an 'Inebriates Home' but it seems that at some stage, young and older women with intellectual disabilities were also accommodated at Graceville. By 1972, Graceville reportedly was involved with the Slow Learning Children's Group workshops and 'special schools' and the Irrabeena assessment program.

In 1974 the property was further developed into the 'Graceville Centre' with additional units for women and their children needing temporary, emergency accommodation (Byanda) and lone women aged 16-25 years with a 'drink problem' (Nunyara). Byanda had previously (1920-1968) been the name of the younger children's building at the Salvation Army Girls' Home, Cottesloe. Byanda and Nunyara were built on the site previously occupied by the Graceville managers' and officers' quarters, facing Smith Street.

The original home was renamed Cornelie and was used to accommodate young and older women with intellectual disabilities who attended special schools and sheltered workshops. Many of these residents had links with Irrabeena. By 1984, this building was called 'Cornelie Hostel'. In March 1986, Cornelie was demolished and the female residents were transferred to a Baptistcare facility in Bassendean. Eleven new units were built on the site, opening on 13 December 1986 and named 'Cornelie Court'.

The Byanda and Nunyara buildings were decommissioned and new premises redeveloped in 2007. In 2013, the Graceville Centre continued to provide supported accommodation to women experiencing domestic violence or homelessness.

chronItem.event: Location - Graceville Centre was located in the premises formerly known as Cornelie Home in Lincoln Street, Highgate

descriptiveNote.p: Cornelie Home was the former name of the property that became Graceville and later the Graceville Centre.

cpfRelation.relationEntry: Children's Homes Collection held by Salvation Army Heritage Museum WA (1898 - )
State Archives Collection of Western Australia (1829 - )
Department of Aboriginal Affairs [predecessors], Records, Department of Aboriginal Affairs (1886 - 2004)

descriptiveNote.p: When the Seaforth Salvation Army Girls' Home closed, some girls with intellectual disabilities were transferred to the Graceville Centre.
Graceville Centre residents with intellectual disabilities attended Irrabeena programs in the 1970s and 1980s.
Graceville Centre residents attended workshops and 'special schools' run by the Slow Learning Children's Group.

Newspaper Article: Eighty years of social service in West. Aust. remembered at the Graceville Centre

bibref.title: Eighty years of social service in West. Aust. remembered at the Graceville Centre

archref.repository: Salvation Army Heritage Museum WA, Graceville photos file
archref.abstract: 'Graceville, 1973' is a digital copy of a photograph held in the Graceville photos file at the Salvation Army Heritage Museum WA. The caption reads, 'Old Graceville, 1973' and is possibly the rear of the original Cornelie Home.

archref.repository: Salvation Army Heritage Museum WA, Graceville photos file
archref.abstract: 'Graceville Women's Industrial Home' is a digital copy of an undated mounted print in the Graceville photos file held at the Salvation Army Heritage Museum WA. It possibly dates from around the 1920, when a series of images of Homes were produced for a Salvation Army book, Property Souvenir Australia: a record of progress. It is not known when the image was mounted and labelled.

archref.abstract: 'Graceville dining room and kitchen exterior, 1974' is a digital copy of an image in the Graceville photos file held at the Salvation Army Heritage Museum WA.

resourceRelation.relationEntry: Quarterly Newsletter, Historical Society WA Chapter

archref.repository: Salvation Army Heritage Museum WA, Cornelie Court social homes closed file
archref.unittitle: Quarterly Newsletter, Historical Society WA Chapter
archref.abstract: 'Quarterly Newsletter, Historical Society WA Chapter' is a digital copy of an item held in the Cornelie Court social homes closed lever-arch file at the Salvation Army Heritage Museum WA. The item is printed excerpts from the 'Jan/Feb/March 2002' newsletter, which features the Cornelie Home, an overview of the 'social work' activities of the Salvation Army in Western Australia in the early years of the twentieth century.

archref.repository: Salvation Army Heritage Museum WA, Cornelie Court social homes closed file
archref.abstract: 'Cornelie Home, exterior' is a digital copy of an item held in the Cornelie Court social homes closed lever-arch file at the Salvation Army Heritage Museum WA. The item is an undated photocopy with 'Graceville' written on the caption. This may mean the photograph was taken after 1903, when the Cornelie Home's name was changed to Graceville.
